prompt:
Read the following passage about the history of computing:

[BEGIN PASSAGE]
The history of computing spans several centuries, beginning with mechanical devices designed to perform calculations. In 1642, Blaise Pascal invented the Pascaline, a mechanical calculator. Charles Babbage designed the Analytical Engine in 1837, which is considered the first general-purpose computer concept. Ada Lovelace wrote the first algorithm intended for machine processing in 1843. The ENIAC, completed in 1945, was the first electronic general-purpose computer. It weighed 30 tons and occupied 1,800 square feet. The transistor was invented at Bell Labs in 1947 by John Bardeen, Walter Brattain, and William Shockley. The first commercial computer, UNIVAC I, was delivered to the U.S. Census Bureau in 1951. IBM introduced the IBM 701 in 1952. The integrated circuit was invented independently by Jack Kilby at Texas Instruments and Robert Noyce at Fairchild Semiconductor in 1958-1959. Intel released the first commercial microprocessor, the Intel 4004, in 1971. The Apple II was released in 1977, and the IBM PC in 1981. Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989 while working at CERN.
[END PASSAGE]

Question: What year was the transistor invented and who were the three inventors?

Read the following story and track the character movements:

[BEGIN STORY]
Mary started her day in the kitchen making breakfast. She then moved to the living room to watch the news. Her husband John was in the garage fixing his car. At 9 AM, Mary went upstairs to the bedroom to get dressed. John finished in the garage and went to the kitchen for coffee. Mary came back downstairs to the living room. John joined her there with his coffee. At 10 AM, Mary went to the home office to work. John went back to the garage. At noon, both met in the kitchen for lunch. After lunch, Mary returned to the home office while John went to the living room to read. At 3 PM, Mary went to the garden to water plants. John stayed in the living room. At 5 PM, both were in the kitchen preparing dinner.
[END STORY]

Question: At noon, list all the rooms that both Mary and John had visited at least once during the day.

Discount Rules:
- Electronics: 10% off for orders over $50
- Accessories: 15% off for orders over $30
- Premium: 20% off for orders over $200
- Bundle discount: Buy any 3 items, get additional 5% off total
- Member discount: Additional 5% off final price

Note: Discounts are applied in order: Category discount first, then bundle, then member.
[END CATALOG]

Question: A member buys Widget A, Widget B, and Gadget X. What is the final price after all applicable discounts?

Read the following witness statements and identify contradictions:

[BEGIN STATEMENTS]
Witness A (interviewed 2:00 PM):
"I saw the suspect enter the building at approximately 10:30 AM. He was wearing a blue jacket and carrying a black briefcase. He went directly to the elevator."

Witness B (interviewed 2:30 PM):
"The man arrived around 10:15 AM. I remember because I was on my coffee break. He had a red jacket and was carrying a laptop bag. He used the stairs."

Witness C (interviewed 3:00 PM):
"I was at the reception desk when a man in a blue jacket came in at 10:30 AM. He asked me for directions to the third floor and took the elevator. He was carrying a black briefcase."

Witness D (interviewed 3:30 PM):
"I saw someone matching that description in the parking lot at 10:45 AM. He was getting out of a silver sedan, wearing a blue jacket. He entered through the side door."
[END STATEMENTS]

Question: List all the contradictions between the witness statements regarding the suspect's appearance, time of arrival, and method of entry.

Read the following excerpts from a mystery novel:

[EXCERPT 1 - Page 15]
Detective Morris examined the study. The grandfather clock had stopped at 11:47 PM. A half-empty glass of whiskey sat on the desk, and the window was slightly ajar.

[EXCERPT 2 - Page 45]
The maid testified that she had served Mr. Hartford his evening whiskey at precisely 10:30 PM, as was his nightly ritual. She noticed the window was closed at that time.

[EXCERPT 3 - Page 78]
The coroner's report indicated time of death between 11:00 PM and midnight. Cause: blunt force trauma to the head. The weapon was never recovered.

[EXCERPT 4 - Page 112]
Neighbor Mrs. Chen reported hearing a loud crash from the Hartford estate at approximately 11:45 PM. She saw a figure running toward the garden gate moments later.

[EXCERPT 5 - Page 156]
The gardener mentioned that the garden gate had a faulty lock that wouldn't engage properly. He had reported it to Mr. Hartford a week prior.

Question: Based on all the scattered information, construct a timeline of events from 10:30 PM to when Mrs. Chen saw the figure running.

Read the following comparison of three programming languages:

[BEGIN COMPARISON]
Python:
- First Released: 1991
- Typing: Dynamic, strongly typed
- Primary Use Cases: Data science, web development, automation, AI/ML
- Learning Curve: Easy
- Performance: Moderate (interpreted)
- Popular Frameworks: Django, Flask, FastAPI, TensorFlow, PyTorch
- Package Manager: pip
- Community Size: Very Large

Rust:
- First Released: 2010
- Typing: Static, strongly typed
- Primary Use Cases: Systems programming, WebAssembly, CLI tools
- Learning Curve: Steep
- Performance: Very High (compiled, zero-cost abstractions)
- Popular Frameworks: Actix, Rocket, Tokio
- Package Manager: Cargo
- Community Size: Growing rapidly

Go:
- First Released: 2009
- Typing: Static, strongly typed
- Primary Use Cases: Cloud services, microservices, DevOps tools
- Learning Curve: Moderate
- Performance: High (compiled, garbage collected)
- Popular Frameworks: Gin, Echo, Fiber
- Package Manager: go modules
- Community Size: Large
[END COMPARISON]

Question: Which language was released earliest, which has the steepest learning curve, and which two languages share the same typing system characteristics?

Read the following recipe with dependencies:

[BEGIN RECIPE]
Chocolate Lava Cake (Serves 4)

Components to Prepare:

1. Chocolate Ganache (must be made first, needs 30 min to cool):
   - 100g dark chocolate
   - 50ml heavy cream
   - Melt together, then cool until firm

2. Cake Batter (start while ganache cools):
   - 200g butter (must be room temperature)
   - 200g dark chocolate
   - 4 eggs (must be room temperature)
   - 100g sugar
   - 50g flour
   - Melt butter and chocolate, whisk eggs and sugar, combine, add flour

3. Assembly (ganache must be firm):
   - Grease 4 ramekins
   - Fill halfway with batter
   - Place 1 tbsp firm ganache in center
   - Cover with remaining batter

4. Baking:
   - Preheat oven to 200°C (must preheat for 15 min)
   - Bake for 12-14 minutes
   - Let rest 1 minute before inverting

Total Time: 1 hour 15 minutes
[END RECIPE]

Question: If you start at 5:00 PM and want to serve at 6:15 PM, at what time should you start preheating the oven?

Read the following three news articles and synthesize the information:

[ARTICLE 1 - Tech Daily, March 1]
Startup XYZ announced a $50 million Series B funding round led by Venture Capital firm AlphaInvest. The company, founded in 2020 by former Google engineers, has developed an AI-powered supply chain solution.

[ARTICLE 2 - Business Weekly, March 5]
AlphaInvest partner Sarah Kim stated that XYZ's technology could revolutionize logistics. The startup currently serves 50 enterprise clients and plans to expand to Europe by Q3. CEO John Park mentioned the funds would primarily go toward R&D and hiring.

[ARTICLE 3 - Industry Report, March 10]
XYZ competitor LogiTech recently filed for bankruptcy, citing market pressures. Industry analysts suggest this creates an opportunity for XYZ to capture LogiTech's 200+ clients. XYZ's valuation is now estimated at $300 million post-funding.

Question: Based on all three articles, what is XYZ's current client base, what is their post-funding valuation, and what market opportunity has recently emerged?

Read the following employee benefits policy:

[BEGIN POLICY]
Acme Corp Employee Benefits Policy 2024

Vacation Days:
- 0-2 years tenure: 10 days
- 3-5 years tenure: 15 days
- 6-10 years tenure: 20 days
- 10+ years tenure: 25 days

Sick Leave:
- All employees: 10 days per year
- Unused sick days: Up to 5 can roll over

Remote Work:
- Junior (0-2 years): 1 day per week
- Mid-level (3-5 years): 2 days per week
- Senior (6+ years): 3 days per week
- Managers: Flexible arrangement

Bonus Eligibility:
- Must have completed 6 months by December 31
- Performance rating of 3 or above (out of 5)
- No disciplinary actions in current year

Parental Leave:
- Primary caregiver: 16 weeks paid
- Secondary caregiver: 4 weeks paid
- Must have 1 year tenure to qualify
[END POLICY]

Question: An employee joined on July 1, 2021. It is now January 2024. How many vacation days are they entitled to, how many remote work days per week, and are they eligible for parental leave?

Read the following shipping policy with exceptions:

[BEGIN POLICY]
Global Shipping Policy

Standard Rates:
- Domestic (USA): $5.99 flat rate, free over $50
- Canada: $12.99 flat rate, free over $100
- Europe: $19.99 flat rate, free over $150
- Asia-Pacific: $24.99 flat rate, free over $200
- Rest of World: $34.99 flat rate, no free shipping threshold

Exceptions:
1. Oversized items (any dimension > 24 inches): +$15 surcharge, no free shipping
2. Fragile items: +$8 handling fee
3. Hazardous materials: Only domestic, +$25 surcharge, no free shipping
4. Perishables: Only USA and Canada, +$10 cold pack fee
5. Express shipping: 2x standard rate, reduces thresholds by 50%

Combined Rules:
- Multiple exceptions stack additively
- Free shipping threshold applies before surcharges
- Orders with any 'no free shipping' item make entire order ineligible
[END POLICY]

Question: A customer in Europe orders: a regular $80 item, an oversized $40 item, and a fragile $50 item. Calculate the total shipping cost and explain which exceptions apply.
